data.text/markdown: Chapter 5: Pretraining on Unlabeled Data
5.1 Evaluating generative text models
5.1.1 Using GPT to generate text
Utility function to convert from text to token ID
Utility function to convert from token ID to text
This is an example to use the above functions. The output does not make sense because it is not trained yet.

console.name: stdout
console.text:
Output text:
 Every effort moves you rentingetic wasnم refres RexMeCHicular stren

data.text/markdown: 5.1.2 Calculating the text generation loss: cross-entropy and perplexity
To show the way to calculate training loss, these inputs and targets are used.
Get probabilities of next token IDs by using random_model inference

console.name: stdout
console.text: probas.shape=torch.Size([2, 3, 50257])

data.text/markdown: Use greedy way to get next token IDs
Compare token IDs between targets and predicted

console.name: stdout
console.text:
Targets batch 1:  effort moves you
Outputs batch 1:  Armed heNetflix

data.text/markdown: Let's evaluate the differences quantitatively. Get the probabilities (likelihood) for targets in the above result. Remind the probas has (batch_size, num_tokens, vocab_size) shape.
Take log of these to get entropy (or log likelihood).
Get average scores of it. This is called as cross entropy loss.
Minimization of minus log is preferred than maximization of plus log for implementations. This is also called as negative log likelihood (nll).

console.name: stdout
console.text: tensor(10.7940)

data.text/markdown: We proceed these calculate by PyTorch. Before doing so, check the shapes of logits and targets to compare.

console.name: stdout
console.text:
Logits shape: torch.Size([2, 3, 50257])
Targets shape: torch.Size([2, 3])

data.text/markdown: To apply PyTorch function, flatten is needed.

console.name: stdout
console.text:
Flattened logits: torch.Size([6, 50257])
Flattened targets: torch.Size([6])

data.text/markdown: Then, pass these to cross_entropy to take softmax, log, mean and the minus. This results coincides the previous result.

console.name: stdout
console.text: tensor(10.7940)

data.text/markdown: The exponential of cross entropy is called as perplexity. If the probabilistic distribution is uniform (the most uncertain case), we can write the perplexity by using the size of vocabulary ||(N||) as ||[ PP =\exp\left(-\sum_{i=1}^N\frac{1}{N}\log\frac{1}{N}\right) =\exp\left(-\log\frac{1}{N}\right)=N. ||]So it has meaning of uncertainty for prediction in the unit of number of vocabularies.
5.1.3 Calculating the training and validation set losses
Calculate such loss on public and tiny dataset. At first, it should be downloaded.

data.text/markdown: Create directory to save plots for the traning process
Define the function to plot training processes
The result shows overfitting because of traning with tiny dataset.
5.3 Decoding strategies to control randomness
The generate_text_simple is based on greedy decoding strategy and it is deterministic.

console.name: stdout
console.text:
Output text:
 Every effort moves you?"

"Yes--quite insensible to the irony. She wanted him vindicated--and by me!"

data.text/markdown: 5.3.1 Temperature scaling
This is an example to show difference between deterministic and probabilistic strategies. This outputs deterministic result by greedy decoding.

console.name: stdout
console.text: forward

data.text/markdown: Try probabilistic sampling based of probabilities obtained by the logits. Even the forward occurs in high probability, it also outputs the same word.

console.name: stdout
console.text: forward

data.text/markdown: Try multiple times to see the probabilistic behaviors.

console.name: stdout
console.text:
73 x closer
0 x every
0 x effort
582 x forward
2 x inches
0 x moves
0 x pizza
343 x toward
0 x you

data.text/markdown: To control the probability, introduce temprature scaling like $$ p(x;\beta) \propto \exp\left(\beta p\right) $$
Try different values of the tempretures.
Plot it. It shows higher temprature make the distribution more uniform.
Temperature=0.1 case causes more greedy like distribution.

console.name: stdout
console.text:
0 x closer
0 x every
0 x effort
985 x forward
0 x inches
0 x moves
0 x pizza
15 x toward
0 x you

data.text/markdown: Temperature=5 cause more diversity but more nonsense phrases like pizza.

console.name: stdout
console.text:
165 x closer
75 x every
42 x effort
239 x forward
71 x inches
46 x moves
32 x pizza
227 x toward
103 x you

data.text/markdown: 5.3.2 Top-k sampling
The top-k sampling strategy is another probabilistic model using cutoff. We only use top ||(k||) candidates in the probabilistic ranking and ignore others.

console.name: stdout
console.text:
Top logits: tensor([6.7500, 6.2800, 4.5100])
Top positions: tensor([3, 7, 0])

data.text/markdown: Such ignored candidate logits are masked by -inf.

console.name: stdout
console.text: tensor([4.5100,   -inf,   -inf, 6.7500,   -inf,   -inf,   -inf, 6.2800,   -inf])

data.text/markdown: The result probabilities are these. The predicted token will be sampled base on this result.
5.3.3 Modifying the text generation function
Include temperature and tok-k sampling to generate_text_simple(). This generation process continues until the EOS token appears.
This result is different with the previous.
